fields.title: If Our Two Loves Be One
Give Me Your Arm Old Toad
The Grave's a Fine and Private Place
Wordsworth on the City of London

fields.description: Chinua Achebe is a Nigerian novelist, poet, professor, and critic. He is best known for his first novel and magnum opus, Things Fall Apart, which is the most widely read book in modern African literature
Rupert Chawner Brooke was an English poet known for his idealistic war sonnets written during the First World War, especially "The Soldier". He was also known for his boyish good looks...
Robert Browning was an English poet and playwright whose mastery of dramatic verse, especially dramatic monologues, made him one of the foremost Victorian poets.
John Donne was an English poet, satirist, lawyer and a cleric in the Church of England. He is considered the pre-eminent representative of the metaphysical poets.

Seamus Heaney is an Irish poet, playwright, translator, lecturer and recipient of the 1995 Nobel Prize in Literature. Born at Mossbawn farmhouse between Castledawson and Toomebridge, he now resides in Dublin.

Philip Arthur Larkin, was an English poet and novelist. His first book of poetry, The North Ship, was published in 1945, followed by two novels, Jill (1946) and A Girl in Winter (1947), but he came to prominence in 1955 with the publication of his second collection of poems, The Less Deceived, followed by The Whitsun Weddings (1964) and High Windows (1974). He contributed to The Daily Telegraph as its jazz critic from 1961 to 1971, articles gathered together in All What Jazz: A Record Diary 1961–71 (1985), and he edited The Oxford Book of Twentieth Century English Verse (1973).[1] He was the recipient of many honours, including the Queen's Gold Medal for Poetry.[2] He was offered, but declined, the position of poet laureate in 1984, following the death of John Betjeman.

Andrew Marvell was an English metaphysical poet and politician who sat in the House of Commons at various times between 1659 and 1678. As a metaphysical poet, he is associated with John Donne and George Herbert.
Wilfred Edward Salter Owen MC was an English poet and soldier, one of the leading poets of the First World War.

Dylan Marlais Thomas was a Welsh poet and writer whose works include poems, stories and radio broadcasts. He became popular in his lifetime, and remained popular after his death; partly due to his larger than life character, and his reputation for drinking to excess.
William Wordsworth was a major English Romantic poet who, with Samuel Taylor Coleridge, helped to launch the Romantic Age in English literature with the 1798 joint publication Lyrical Ballads.

William Butler Yeats was an Irish poet and one of the foremost figures of 20th century literature. A pillar of both the Irish and British literary establishments, in his later years he served as an Irish Senator for two terms.

fields.text:
Between my finger and my thumb
The squat pen rests; as snug as a gun.

Under my window a clean rasping sound
When the spade sinks into gravelly ground:
My father, digging. I look down

Till his straining rump among the flowerbeds
Bends low, comes up twenty years away
Stooping in rhythm through potato drills
Where he was digging.

The coarse boot nestled on the lug, the shaft
Against the inside knee was levered firmly.
He rooted out tall tops, buried the bright edge deep
To scatter new potatoes that we picked
Loving their cool hardness in our hands.

By God, the old man could handle a spade,
Just like his old man.

My grandfather could cut more turf in a day
Than any other man on Toner's bog.
Once I carried him milk in a bottle
Corked sloppily with paper. He straightened up
To drink it, then fell to right away
Nicking and slicing neatly, heaving sods
Over his shoulder, digging down and down
For the good turf. Digging.

The cold smell of potato mold, the squelch and slap
Of soggy peat, the curt cuts of an edge
Through living roots awaken in my head.
But I've no spade to follow men like them.

Between my finger and my thumb
The squat pen rests.
I'll dig with it.
fields.title: Digging

fields.text:
Do not go gentle into that good night,
Old age should burn and rave at close of day;
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

Though wise men at their end know dark is right,
Because their words had forked no lightning they
Do not go gentle into that good night.

Good men, the last wave by, crying how bright
Their frail deeds might have danced in a green bay,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

Wild men who caught and sang the sun in flight,
And learn, too late, they grieved it on its way,
Do not go gentle into that good night.

Grave men, near death, who see with blinding sight
Blind eyes could blaze like meteors and be gay,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

And you, my father, there on that sad height,
Curse, bless, me now with your fierce tears, I pray.
Do not go gentle into that good night.
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.
fields.title: Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night

fields.text:
Bent double, like old beggars under sacks,
Knock-kneed, coughing like hags, we cursed through sludge,
Till on the haunting flares we turned our backs
And towards our distant rest began to trudge.
Men marched asleep. Many had lost their boots
But limped on, blood-shod. All went lame; all blind;
Drunk with fatigue; deaf even to the hoots
Of disappointed shells that dropped behind.

GAS! Gas! Quick, boys!-- An ecstasy of fumbling,
Fitting the clumsy helmets just in time;
But someone still was yelling out and stumbling
And floundering like a man in fire or lime.--
Dim, through the misty panes and thick green light
As under a green sea, I saw him drowning.

In all my dreams, before my helpless sight,
He plunges at me, guttering, choking, drowning.

If in some smothering dreams you too could pace
Behind the wagon that we flung him in,
And watch the white eyes writhing in his face,
His hanging face, like a devil's sick of sin;
If you could hear, at every jolt, the blood
Come gargling from the froth-corrupted lungs,
Obscene as cancer, bitter as the cud
Of vile, incurable sores on innocent tongues,--
My friend, you would not tell with such high zest
To children ardent for some desperate glory,
The old Lie: Dulce et decorum est
Pro patria mori.
fields.title: Dulce et Decorum Est

fields.text:
I sat all morning in the college sick bay
Counting bells knelling classes to a close.
At two o'clock our neighbors drove me home.

In the porch I met my father crying--
He had always taken funerals in his stride--
And Big Jim Evans saying it was a hard blow.

The baby cooed and laughed and rocked the pram
When I came in, and I was embarrassed
By old men standing up to shake my hand

And tell me they were 'sorry for my trouble,'
Whispers informed strangers I was the eldest,
Away at school, as my mother held my hand

In hers and coughed out angry tearless sighs.
At ten o'clock the ambulance arrived
With the corpse, stanched and bandaged by the nurses.

Next morning I went up into the room. Snowdrops
And candles soothed the bedside; I saw him
For the first time in six weeks. Paler now,

Wearing a poppy bruise on his left temple,
He lay in the four foot box as in his cot.
No gaudy scars, the bumper knocked him clear.

A four foot box, a foot for every year.
fields.title: Mid-Term Break

fields.text:
That’s my last Duchess painted on the wall, 
Looking as if she were alive. I call 
That piece a wonder, now: Fra Pandolf’s hands 
Worked busily a day, and there she stands. 
Will’t please you sit and look at her? I said 
“Fra Pandolf” by design, for never read 
Strangers like you that pictured countenance, 
The depth and passion of its earnest glance, 
But to myself they turned (since none puts by 
The curtain I have drawn for you, but I) 
And seemed as they would ask me, if they durst, 
How such a glance came there; so, not the first 
Are you to turn and ask thus. Sir, ’twas not 
Her husband’s presence only, called that spot 
Of joy into the Duchess’ cheek: perhaps 
Fra Pandolf chanced to say “Her mantle laps 
Over my lady’s wrist too much,” or “Paint 
Must never hope to reproduce the faint 
Half-flush that dies along her throat”: such stuff 
Was courtesy, she thought, and cause enough 
For calling up that spot of joy. She had 
A heart—how shall I say?—too soon made glad, 
Too easily impressed; she liked whate’er 
She looked on, and her looks went everywhere. 
Sir, ’twas all one! My favour at her breast, 
The dropping of the daylight in the West, 
The bough of cherries some officious fool 
Broke in the orchard for her, the white mule 
She rode with round the terrace—all and each 
Would draw from her alike the approving speech, 
Or blush, at least. She thanked men,—good! but thanked 
Somehow—I know not how—as if she ranked 
My gift of a nine-hundred-years-old name 
With anybody’s gift. Who’d stoop to blame 
This sort of trifling? Even had you skill 
In speech—(which I have not)—to make your will 
Quite clear to such an one, and say, “Just this 
Or that in you disgusts me; here you miss, 
Or there exceed the mark”—and if she let 
Herself be lessoned so, nor plainly set 
Her wits to yours, forsooth, and made excuse, 
—E’en then would be some stooping; and I choose 
Never to stoop. Oh sir, she smiled, no doubt, 
Whene’er I passed her; but who passed without 
Much the same smile? This grew; I gave commands; 
Then all smiles stopped together. There she stands 
As if alive. Will’t please you rise? We’ll meet 
The company below, then. I repeat, 
The Count your master’s known munificence 
Is ample warrant that no just pretence 
Of mine for dowry will be disallowed; 
Though his fair daughter’s self, as I avowed 
At starting, is my object. Nay, we’ll go 
Together down, sir. Notice Neptune, though, 
Taming a sea-horse, thought a rarity, 
Which Claus of Innsbruck cast in bronze for me!
fields.title: My Last Duchess

fields.text:
Why should I blame her that she filled my days
With misery, or that she would of late
Have taught to ignorant men most violent ways,
Or hurled the little streets upon the great,
Had they but courage equal to desire?
What could have made her peaceful with a mind
That nobleness made simple as a fire,
With beauty like a tightened bow, a kind
That is not natural in an age like this,
Being high and solitary and most stern?
Why, what could she have done, being as she is?
Was there another Troy for her to burn?
fields.title: No Second Troy

fields.text:
No Madonna and Child could touch
that picture of a mother's tenderness
for a son she soon would have to forget.
The air was heavy with odours
of diarrhoea of unwashed children
with washed-out ribs and dried-up
bottoms struggling in laboured
steps behind blown empty bellies. Most
mothers there had long ceased
to care but not this one; she held
a ghost smile between her teeth
and in her eyes the ghost of a mother's
pride as she combed the rust-coloured
hair left on his skull and then -
singing in her eyes - began carefully
to part it...In another life this
must have been a little daily
act of no consequence before his
breakfast and school; now she
did it like putting flowers
on a tiny grave.
fields.title: Refugee Mother and her Child

fields.text:
I wonder, by my troth, what thou and I
Did, till we loved? Were we not weaned till then?
But sucked on country pleasures, childishly?
Or snorted we in the Seven Sleepers’ den?
’Twas so; but this, all pleasures fancies be.
If ever any beauty I did see,
Which I desired, and got, ’twas but a dream of thee.

And now good-morrow to our waking souls,
Which watch not one another out of fear;
For love, all love of other sights controls,
And makes one little room an everywhere.
Let sea-discoverers to new worlds have gone,
Let maps to other, worlds on worlds have shown,
Let us possess one world, each hath one, and is one.

My face in thine eye, thine in mine appears,
And true plain hearts do in the faces rest;
Where can we find two better hemispheres,
Without sharp north, without declining west?
Whatever dies, was not mixed equally;
If our two loves be one, or, thou and I
Love so alike, that none do slacken, none can die.
fields.title: The Good Morrow

fields.text:
If I should die, think only this of me:
That there's some corner of a foreign field
That is for ever England. There shall be
In that rich earth a richer dust concealed;
A dust whom England bore, shaped, made aware,
Gave, once, her flowers to love, her ways to roam,
A body of England's, breathing English air,
Washed by the rivers, blest by suns of home.

And think, this heart, all evil shed away,
A pulse in the eternal mind, no less
Gives somewhere back the thoughts by England given;
Her sights and sounds; dreams happy as her day;
And laughter, learnt of friends; and gentleness,
In hearts at peace, under an English heaven.
fields.title: The Soldier

fields.text:
Why should I let the toad work
Squat on my life?
Can’t I use my wit as a pitchfork
And drive the brute off?

Six days of the week it soils
With its sickening poison -
Just for paying a few bills!
That’s out of proportion.

Lots of folk live on their wits:
Lecturers, lispers,
Losers, loblolly-men, louts-
They don’t end as paupers;

Lots of folk live up lanes
With fires in a bucket,
Eat windfalls and tinned sardines-
They seem to like it.

Their nippers have got bare feet,
Their unspeakable wives
Are skinny as whippets - and yet
No one actually _starves_.

Ah, were I courageous enough
To shout, Stuff your pension!
But I know, all too well, that’s the stuff
That dreams are made on:

For something sufficiently toad-like
Squats in me, too;
Its hunkers are heavy as hard luck,
And cold as snow,

And will never allow me to blarney
My way of getting
The fame and the girl and the money
All at one sitting.

I don’t say, one bodies the other
One’s spiritual truth;
But I do say it’s hard to lose either,
When you have both.
fields.title: Toads

fields.text:
Walking around in the park
Should feel better than work:
The lake, the sunshine,
The grass to lie on,

Blurred playground noises
Beyond black-stockinged nurses -
Not a bad place to be.
Yet it doesn't suit me.

Being one of the men
You meet of an afternoon:
Palsied old step-takers,
Hare-eyed clerks with the jitters,

Waxed-fleshed out-patients
Still vague from accidents,
And characters in long coats
Deep in the litter-baskets -

All dodging the toad work
By being stupid or weak.
Think of being them!
Hearing the hours chime,

Watching the bread delivered,
The sun by clouds covered,
The children going home;
Think of being them,

Turning over their failures
By some bed of lobelias,
Nowhere to go but indoors,
Nor friends but empty chairs -

No, give me my in-tray,
My loaf-haired secretary,
My shall-I-keep-the-call-in-Sir:
What else can I answer,

When the lights come on at four
At the end of another year?
Give me your arm, old toad;
Help me down Cemetery Road.
fields.title: Toads Revisited

fields.text:
Had we but world enough, and time,
This coyness, Lady, were no crime.
We would sit down and think which way
To walk and pass our long love's day.
Thou by the Indian Ganges' side
Shouldst rubies find: I by the tide
Of Humber would complain. I would
Love you ten years before the Flood,
And you should, if you please, refuse
Till the conversion of the Jews.
My vegetable love should grow
Vaster than empires, and more slow;
An hundred years should go to praise
Thine eyes and on thy forehead gaze;
Two hundred to adore each breast;
But thirty thousand to the rest;
An age at least to every part,
And the last age should show your heart;
For, Lady, you deserve this state,
Nor would I love at lower rate.

But at my back I always hear
Time's wingèd chariot hurrying near;
And yonder all before us lie
Deserts of vast eternity.
Thy beauty shall no more be found,
Nor, in thy marble vault, shall sound
My echoing song: then worms shall try
That long preserved virginity,
And your quaint honour turn to dust,
And into ashes all my lust:
The grave's a fine and private place,
But none, I think, do there embrace.

Now therefore, while the youthful hue
Sits on thy skin like morning dew,
And while thy willing soul transpires
At every pore with instant fires,
Now let us sport us while we may,
And now, like amorous birds of prey,
Rather at once our time devour
Than languish in his slow-chapt power.
Let us roll all our strength and all
Our sweetness up into one ball,
And tear our pleasures with rough strife
Thorough the iron gates of life:
Thus, though we cannot make our sun
Stand still, yet we will make him run.
fields.title: To His Coy Mistress

fields.text:
Earth has not anything to show more fair:
Dull would he be of soul who could pass by
A sight so touching in its majesty:
This City now doth like a garment wear

The beauty of the morning: silent, bare,
Ships, towers, domes, theatres, and temples lie
Open unto the fields, and to the sky,
All bright and glittering in the smokeless air.

Never did sun more beautifully steep
In his first splendour valley, rock, or hill;
Ne'er saw I, never felt, a calm so deep!

The river glideth at his own sweet will:
Dear God! the very houses seem asleep;
And all that mighty heart is lying still!
fields.title: Upon Westminster Bridge
Digging
fields.synopsis: Seamus Heaney’s Mission Statement poem. The first poem from his first book of verse, the one that sets out what he intends to do in his poetry, and the kind of poet he wants to be. Digging is that, but it is also a celebration of family tradition and how it can be used and moulded by the next generation who may have different work and different tools but still finds an ethic to emulate.

fields.title: Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night
fields.synopsis: The most anthologized example of a villanelle in English poetry and Thomas’s cry to his dying father not to peacefully accept his coming death. We may ask though, who is the poet really trying to convince? Thomas work is often difficult to paraphrase, but not impossible. This lecture provides ‘a way in’ to a difficult but often rewarding poet, and an explanation of the specific poetic form he chooses to employ in this justifiably famous wok.

fields.title: Dulce et Decorum
fields.synopsis: Arguably the greatest anti-war poem yet written, Dulche Et Decorm Est was composed near the end of the first world war by a poet who had actually experienced the horrors of the trenches. Owen gives us the reality behind the war-time recruiting phrase “It is sweet and fitting to die for your country,” as he recounts a friend’s death during a gas attack. Containing, for me, some of poetry’s most powerful moments. “If you could hear at every jolt the blood/ Come gargling from the froth corrupted lungs.”

fields.title: Mid-Term Break
fields.synopsis: One of the finest “Introduction to Poetry” verses I know. A child returns from boarding school for the funeral of a relative. The lecture concentrates on the suspense involved in the first reading of the poem when the reader does not know the plot, does not know what is going to happen, does not know who has died. Some of the most beautiful lines in literature, “Snowdrops and candles soothed the bedside/ I saw him for the first time in six weeks/ paler now.”

fields.title: My Last Duchess
fields.synopsis: A widowed Duke about to meet his new bride stops a messenger on the stairs to reveal a portrait. Thus begins Browning’s tale of jealousy and homicide. What type of woman was the last Duchess? What type of man is the Duke who speaks the poem to the messenger, and us? A piece that cries out to be acted provided the actor understands the character of the Duke. The lecture takes us through the Duke’s complaints against his previous wife to show us the psychology of the man giving us the information.

fields.title: No Second Troy
fields.synopsis: Yeats looks back on years of unrequited love, to assess the people of Ireland as he has known them in their relationship to the object of his oft spurned affection, Maude Gonne. The lecture gives background on Yeats and Gonne, and the Ireland of the time that the poem was composed. A marvellous work in its own right, and one that begs comparison with Yeats’s later work Easter 1916.

fields.title: Refugee Mother and her Child
fields.synopsis: A haunting representation of tragedy in the aftermath of tragedy. Chinua Achebe’s, never mawkish word picture of a mother holding her dying child manages to be both tender and tough. Rarely has so much emotion been packed into such a short work.

fields.title: The Good Morrow
fields.synopsis: A love poem from the morning. Upon waking, a man feels a new kind of love for the woman he is with. This poem is what he tells her. What was their relationship like? How has it changed? What will their love be like in the future? The lecture look at post the confidence and the vulnerability of the one who speaks the beautiful lines that make up The Good Morrow.

fields.title: The Soldier
fields.synopsis: Written just before the first world war The Soldier was used as a recruiting poem for that particular engagement. Yet the man who wrote it had very limited experience of warfare. How far is this still very famous piece, a piece of out dated jingoism? Or how far can it be seen as a love poem to England? This lecture presents the arguments for both.

fields.title: Toads
fields.notes:
1. The lecture begins by looking Philip Larkin’s character, who he was and what he was trying to do in his poetry.
  2. The poem is read through.
  3. The metaphor of the Toad is explained.
  4. The poem is parsed, paraphrased, explained line by line in simpler English.
  5. Various complications noted, or areas of interest raised and questioned, are:
    • Larkin’s dislike of the lecturer poet.
    • The class element in what Larkin writes.
    • How Larkin expects us to view the persona who narrates the poem in the way he addresses the working classes.
    • The self-awareness of the persona in analysing his own motivation.
    • The metaphor of the second toad.
  6. A summary of the poem is then given.
  7. Larkin’s achievement in the writing of the poem is assessed.
  8. From the Lecture: “Larkin may not get the fame, the girl, or the money, but he gets the poem.”
  9. The lecture concludes with a final read through of the poem.
fields.synopsis: A middle class man in a job he hates contemplates what would happen if he resigned to follow his dreams. One of those poems that touches a nerve in many readers. Larkin’s central metaphor or “the toad work” being all too familiar. Yet why is it that he cannot leave his? What is the other toad that squats in him too that prevents? And why has Larkin allowed himself to become the man who can narrate this poem?

fields.title: Toads Revisited
fields.synopsis: Philip Larkin’s sequel to Toads finds him walking around a park on a sunny day contemplating the fact that the toad work has been avoided for at least an afternoon. Brilliantly evocative of the of the increasing allure of middle class trappings as we age, Toads Revisited concludes with some of Larkin’s most depressingly imagery as he accepts and even appreciates the job he has previously despised.

fields.title: To His Coy Mistress
fields.synopsis: Andrew Marvell’s seventeenth centaury seduction poem remains one of our best representations of the metaphysical poet’s call to seize the day. Moving from the whimsical to the vulgar to the inspirational To His Coy Mistress, is an argument to attract a lover, but also a metaphor for not missing out on those fleeting moments of unusual and exceptional  happiness life provides for us.

fields.title: Upon Westminster Bridge
fields.synopsis: Often misrepresented as a love poem to the city of London, William Wordsworth’s Westminster Bridge is more a love poem to the morning. And what beauty he shows us in his presentation of London sunrise. The lecture is presented in tandem with an assessment of Wordsworth’s famous description of poetry as “the spontaneous overflow of powerful feelings: it takes its origin from emotion recollected in tranquillity.” Is poetry that? Always?

fields.name: Dr. Mike Ingham
fields.text: This is a wonderful resource for students who wish to access English language poetry and understand both form and function, that is the structural elements and also the feelings and ideas that are conveyed in the poem. Dr Barker’s subject expertise and enthusiasm for poetry shines through in these informative, insightful and original lecturettes. The beauty of this site is that students can glean greater understanding and appreciation of great anglophone poetry at both secondary school and university undergraduate level. Such a combination of range and depth is rare and valuable for people who care about literature pedagogy and also for those who seek to enter the world of the poetic imagination. Highly recommended!

fields.name: Dr. Jessica Yeung
fields.text: Mycroft is, as we all know from the Sherlock Holmes stories, Sherlock’s even smarter brother. However, it doesn’t take a genius to see that the Mycroft online lectures really can benefit my second-language students. They find English language poetry extremely challenging, and for my MA and undergraduate students it is essential for them to have some exposure to the cultural experience of poetry in English as well as in Chinese, if they are to appreciate poetry translation in both language directions. The Mycroft lectures have really succeeded in opening up the world of English language poetry to my students. Thanks to the happy blend of clarity and analytical rigour evident in the structure and execution of the lectures, we now have a valuable self-study aid as well as a dynamic teaching tool in class. For Translation students this is an ideal study aid because the lectures draw them into the world of the poem, clearly explicating the cultural background, the metaphors and layers of meaning, the language devices and subtext, as well as offering insights into the personality of the poet and the wider context of the poem. I recommend the Mycroft lectures on poetry very strongly for fellow teachers of literature both to whet the appetite for and stimulate the interest in poetry among their students and, at the same time, provide a practical resource for those who find English language poetry rather forbidding. A valuable addition to the world of online resources, Mycroft’s excellence lies in its attention to every detail of the student’s fundamental needs in the understanding and appreciation of an impressive range of famous English poems. Thoroughly recommended for my Hong Kong as well as for international students in general!
fields.credentials: Associate Professor Dept of English, Translation Programme, Hong Kong Baptist University.

fields.name: Martin Alexander
fields.text: Students of poetry in English will enjoy and be stimulated by Dr Barker’s close readings of this series of poems. The selection features poems regularly included on exam syllabuses and often taught in senior secondary school classes. His analysis and exploration of the poetry leads the viewer to a close understanding of how each poet has arrived at a distinctive, memorable and striking articulation of the human condition. Barker has won recognition for his teaching style, and it shows.
fields.credentials:
Editor. Asia Literary Review.
Former Head of English at Island School.

fields.name: Dilip Barad, Ph.D.
fields.text:
Dear Dr. Andrew Barker,

I saw sample lectures on poetry on www.mycroft-online-lectures.com
I am impressed by your work. It is indeed, very helpful resource for the students as well as teachers of English literature. Most of the poems you have dealt are in curriculum of Indian universities.

What I liked:

- Slow and steady pace of your speech –helpful to students and grasping the ideas…
- Some lines of poems written on the screen –this is very good… and I hope the entire poem must be visible to the viewers in full video.
- Analysis is quite up to the mark of university level.

A valuable resource and an excellent work by Dr. Andrew Barker
fields.credentials:
Professor & Head, Dept. of English, Maharaja Krishnakumarsinhji Bhavnagar University,
www.dilipbarad.com
www.facebook.com/dilipbarad

fields.name: Reid Mitchell
fields.text: A splendid series of lectures, delivered with intelligence, vigor, and rare humor. I recommend Dr. Barker’s material highly to both students, teachers, and all lovers of literature. Besides the joy of appreciating some of the greatest poems in the English languages, viewers will learn the principles of analysis necessary both for the enjoyment of poetry and academic success. Therefore I particularly recommend these lectures to all of you preparing for such examinations as the IB.
fields.credentials:
Fulbright Lecturer in American Studies, Hong Kong University, 2005-2006
English Language Teacher, Tsinghua University, Beijing.

fields.name: Jenny Wong
fields.text: An innovative and user-friendly resource for literary studies on contemporary poets, and a source of inspiration for both teachers and students.

fields.name: Akin Jeje
fields.text: I think that this online lecture series is an invaluable tool for any student of English poetry. Students are able to visualize the poem through Dr. Barker’s lecture, rather than just attempt to grasp potentially arcane meaning and symbolism by themselves. Definitely recommended!

fields.name: Meena Kandasamy
fields.text:
Reminiscent of John Keating in Dead Poets Society, Dr Andrew Barker approaches poetry with a passion that draws the student/viewer to engage with the poem not just as a text to be understood with the aid of annotations but as an experience. He blends the seriousness of the literary critic with the intimate exuberance of a poet; so, it is a delight to watch him explain a love poem by hauling John Donne from the seventeenth century to a contemporary milieu, or, hear him shrewdly unwrap the layers of meaning in Seamus Heaney’s Digging.

Mycroft lectures include a comprehensive selection of poems many of which are on the English literature syllabi of several Indian universities. Apart from understanding the contexts, nuances, metaphors and poetic devices incorporated in the poems, students will also immensely benefit from observing the language and method employed to discuss poetry.

These poetry lectures can also be incorporated in ESL classrooms to wean away students from the preconceived notion that language learning is merely gaining command over a set of communication skills, and to give these students a taste of English literature, to allow them to partake of its beauty and its brilliance. I recommend these lectures strongly and I believe that they will be amazing teaching resources in English language classrooms.

fields.description:
Licensing Mycroft for a semester will mean that all staff and all students will have access to all lectures for the duration of that semester.

Schools are free to build courses around the lectures or to use them to augment existing courses. Teachers can set the lectures for homework, and follow up on them for classroom discussion. Should teachers be absent, substitute teachers need only sit in on a room where a lecture is shown, for the class teacher to follow up on the issues raised in that lecture later.

The lectures are timed to be the appropriate length to be shown as a school, college or university lecture.

All poems on Mycroft are on syllabi and provide specific information needed for the passing of examinations. Should the poem lectured on not be on the syllabus your school is addressing the analysis within the lecture will still provide invaluable ‘tools’ for examination of poems within the syllabus. To this end, teachers may select not to show a full lecture but to select section they feel address areas they wish to cover in class.

The lectures are designed to appeal to and be useful to a wide section of students. Some students will find them easier than others and disagreement about the most interesting interpretation of a poem for discussion among students is encouraged within the lectures themselves.

Finally, though we have been very careful to ensure the lectures are easy to understand and cover explanations of the poems, these lectures contain very little “fat.” Each lecture contains a lot of information. Students at school or college level will be able to understand the poems after watching the lectures. Students at university level will find new points for consideration and analysis.

Remember, once you have listened Mycroft for a semester all the lectures can be viewed as many times as you wish for all staff and all students.
fields.name: Institutional License
